title: R42562
content: The Moving to Work (MTW) demonstration program, created in 1996 by Congress, allows HUD and PHAs to test alternative policies for housing assistance. Over 30 PHAs participate in MTW, managing billions in funding. The future of MTW is uncertain, with calls for changes before the 2018 expiration of current agreements. Critics argue that MTW agencies have too much flexibility without clear outcomes. The Moving to Work (MTW) demonstration program allows PHAs to test alternative housing assistance policies. There are conflicting views on the program's impact, with some arguing for its expansion and others calling for changes or its end. Evaluating the effectiveness of MTW agencies' policies is challenging, leading to uncertainty about the program's future. The Moving to Work (MTW) demonstration program allows PHAs to test alternative housing assistance policies. Some believe it should be restructured to better serve its purpose, while others see it as a successful model for future assisted housing programs. MTW agencies have influenced reforms in mainstream housing programs, and policymakers may consider lessons from the program for future housing assistance reforms. The Moving to Work Demonstration Program, authorized by Congress in 1996, allows PHAs to test new approaches for providing housing assistance to low-income families. The program aims to reduce costs, promote self-sufficiency, and increase housing choices. Up to 30 PHAs can participate in the program, with evaluations conducted for up to 15 agencies to identify successful models. The program's legislative guidelines are broad, allowing agencies to develop and test their own policies for assisted housing. The Moving to Work Demonstration Program, authorized by Congress in 1996, allows PHAs to test new approaches for providing housing assistance to low-income families. The program aims to reduce costs, promote self-sufficiency, and increase housing choices. PHAs have flexibility to combine funding streams, design rent policies, and be held harmless in terms of funding. However, there are limits on the flexibility allowed, such as serving the same number and size-mix of families, ensuring a majority are low-income, and meeting housing quality standards. HUD cannot waive certain provisions of the U.S. Housing Act for MTW agencies. The Moving to Work Demonstration Program, authorized by Congress in 1996, allows PHAs to test new approaches for providing housing assistance to low-income families. PHAs must seek public input in developing their MTW policies, hold public hearings, and incorporate public comments into their MTW application plan. The plan must be approved by HUD for participation in the program, with agencies required to submit annual reports on fund usage and activities. This allows MTW agencies to implement various policies and activities under the program. The MTW demonstration program was developed in response to concerns about rising costs and decaying public housing. Federal policymakers considered block granting to local officials for greater autonomy in designing programs. Some policymakers and tenant advocates were not in favor of this strategy. The MTW demonstration program was created to address concerns about increasing costs and deteriorating public housing. It allowed for local autonomy in program design while aiming to achieve federal housing goals. HUD announced the program in 1996, receiving 43 applications and selecting 30 PHAs for participation. The negotiation process for the MTW agreements was complex and lengthy. The MTW negotiation process was complicated and lengthy, with agreements reached in 1998 or 1999. Some agencies opted out due to delays or increased flexibility in housing programs. Additional PHAs were added through acts of Congress, expanding the program beyond the original cap of 30 PHAs. HUD selected nine PHAs to participate in the MTW program through various acts of Congress, with a focus on high-performing PHAs with fewer than 5,000 housing units. Currently, 35 PHAs are part of the program, with four more agencies selected by HUD. Criticisms of the program include poor performance selection, lack of uniformity in program structure, and limitations in data systems for policy variations. HUD's data systems were unable to accommodate variations in PHA income and rent policies, hindering data collection from MTW PHAs. This led to a lack of information on tenant characteristics, making it difficult to evaluate the effects of MTW policies on tenant outcomes and program costs. Despite issuing reports on MTW, evaluations have been process-oriented and limited in scope. Criticisms from the Inspector General and GAO prompted HUD to standardize MTW agreements in 2008 to improve monitoring and oversight. The standard MTW agreements extended agencies' participation in the program until 2018, allowing for more systematic evaluation of policies. HUD has increased monitoring efforts to ensure compliance with statutory purposes. Definitions of key terms like "self-sufficiency" and "housing choice" remain undefined. HUD collects data on tenant characteristics to evaluate outcomes and costs. HUD plans to require MTW agencies to define "self-sufficiency" and "housing choice" and collect data on a "comparable mix of families." A review found that 91% of individuals served by MTW agencies were low-income. While HUD's initiatives aim to ensure compliance with statutory requirements, without standard definitions and a systematic process, full compliance cannot be effectively evaluated. The IG report from September 2013 highlighted HUD's challenges in overseeing the MTW program and recommended no additional agencies be added until improvements were made. MTW agencies have implemented various program activities, with some completely transforming their housing programs. Three policy areas where MTW agencies have discretion include merging funding streams, determining assistance levels, and setting conditions. MTW agencies have the flexibility to merge funding streams, adjust assistance levels, and set conditions for program participants. This "block grant" assistance allows for a combined funding approach, departing from traditional program operations. The report does not evaluate the effectiveness of these policies but notes variations in agency policies and changes over time. MTW agencies have the flexibility to merge funding streams and adjust assistance levels through negotiated agreements. This funding cannot be used for administrative purposes or public housing programs. Agencies used the flexibility to address financial shortfalls and for cross-program purposes approved by HUD. MTW agencies utilize funding flexibility to increase self-sufficiency and develop additional low-income housing units. Some agencies have undertaken ambitious development activities, such as converting public housing stocks to new forms of assistance. Notably, the Chicago Housing Authority and the Atlanta Housing Authority have used their flexibility for significant redevelopment projects. The Chicago Housing Authority and other MTW agencies have used their funding flexibility to attract private investment for redevelopment projects, replacing deteriorating public housing with new developments in mixed-income communities. This fixed 10-year merged funding stream has been key in obtaining financing from private investors, allowing for revenue bond financing and the conversion of public housing to project-based voucher developments. The interest in converting public housing developments into new forms of assistance is driven by leveraging additional outside financing, limited in traditional public housing. Project-basing of vouchers is more widely used by MTW PHAs than non-MTW PHAs, allowing for flexibility in converting public housing stock to project-based vouchers. MTW agencies have the flexibility to convert public housing stock to project-based vouchers, project-base former public housing properties sold to nonprofits, and project-base entire buildings for special populations. The majority of MTW agencies are engaged in project-basing vouchers, a higher rate than non-MTW PHAs. This allows for alternative processes in awarding project-based assistance and can impact the level of assistance provided to tenants. MTW agencies have the discretion to experiment with alternative income calculations and rent structures, but HUD guidance now requires them to use statutory income calculations for determining housing assistance eligibility. They can still implement alternative rent structures and set additional conditions for tenants. Industry groups argue that the current income calculations are complex and discourage income reporting. Some MTW agencies have experimented with alternative income calculations and rent structures to simplify the process and encourage tenants to increase their income. This includes limiting income exclusions, deductions, and disregarding income from assets below a certain threshold. Over half of participating MTW agencies in 2011 used modified income or asset disregard, and a quarter used modified deductions. It is uncertain if these policies will continue in the future due to recent HUD guidance. Most MTW agencies have experimented with reducing the frequency of verifying tenants' income, especially for those with fixed incomes like the elderly or disabled. 88% of MTW agencies use an alternate schedule for recertifying tenant income, potentially forgoing additional revenue or increasing subsidy costs. The cost-effectiveness of this approach is unknown. MTW agencies have experimented with various rent structures, including minimum, maximum, flat rents, delayed rent increases, and alternative subsidies. Most agencies have their own minimum rent policies, some have tiered rent policies, and others have flat rent policies. Additionally, some agencies have simplified the utility calculation component for determining a tenant's subsidy. Some MTW agencies believe alternative rent structures encourage work by not penalizing tenants for income increases, making it easier to understand and administer. However, there is a lack of data to evaluate if these structures have increased tenant earnings. MTW PHAs have also implemented new requirements for tenants, such as time limits and work requirements. Approximately one-third of MTW agencies have implemented work requirements, while half as many have implemented time limit policies to promote self-sufficiency and serve more families. These policies vary in specifications, with time limits ranging from three to seven years. Additional streamlined operations include alternative housing quality inspections and reporting requirements. In the Section 8 Housing Choice Voucher program, rental units must be inspected annually to meet HUD's standards. Some MTW agencies have alternative inspection schedules, such as risk-based inspections, allowing for less frequent inspections and self-certification by landlords. MTW agencies have alternative HQS inspection procedures, with 19% allowing self-certification. HUD's 2010 Report to Congress suggests these procedures ensure housing quality in a less burdensome way. However, a full evaluation is needed to compare effectiveness with traditional inspection procedures. MTW agencies differ in reporting program information to HUD, submitting an Annual MTW Plan and Report outlining their activities for the year. MTW agencies submit an Annual MTW Plan and Report detailing their activities for the year. Non-MTW agencies also submit plans but with a focus on meeting federal rules and regulations. MTW reporting requirements encourage program creativity and strategic planning. Since 2008, new MTW activities must be approved by HUD before implementation. HUD has more knowledge of MTW agencies' activities and outcomes through the Annual MTW Plans. However, the current reporting process allows agencies to self-report without verification. Some agencies have struggled with new reporting requirements, and HUD's reporting systems lack capacity for MTW-specific data. There has been no systematic evaluation of MTW agencies' outcomes in achieving program goals. A more systematic evaluation may be possible in the future as HUD standardizes the program and improves data collection. Despite the lack of verified evidence on the effectiveness of MTW activities, observations from tenant advocates, PHAs, and HUD have influenced policy debates. Concerns have been raised about the impact of MTW policies on assisted housing tenants, with unclear effects. HUD suggests that MTW allows PHAs to provide more housing units, but the overall impact remains unstudied. The Moving to Work (MTW) program has potentially provided benefits to low-income individuals by allowing agencies to assist more families, although this may be due to reducing assistance for current recipients. Some MTW agencies have implemented policies that decrease rental assistance and limit tenants' housing choices. The long-term impact of self-sufficiency programs and work requirements on needy families is uncertain, requiring further research to determine the net benefit of MTW discretion. The MTW program has allowed agencies to assist more families by potentially reducing assistance for current recipients and limiting housing choices. Some MTW agencies have demolished public housing, replacing it with vouchers and mixed-income developments, which has raised concerns among tenant advocates about community destruction and reduced access to social services. Further research is needed to determine the overall impact of MTW discretion on low-income individuals. The HOPE VI program has funded the demolition or redevelopment of severely distressed public housing, showing positive results for tenants in lower-poverty neighborhoods with improved health outcomes. However, vulnerable tenants may not benefit as much and may require additional services. Data on the cost-effectiveness of MTW agencies in administering housing programs is insufficient, but supporters generally believe in its success. Supporters of the MTW program believe it has been successful in improving cost effectiveness and efficiency in administering assisted housing. However, not everyone agrees, as some argue that MTW agencies actually have higher costs than non-MTW agencies and negatively impact funding for other PHAs. Congress has shown support for the program by expanding participation, but there are differing opinions on its overall effectiveness. MTW agencies have increased discretion and self-defined outcome goals, which supporters argue reduces administrative burdens and allows for innovative strategies. Unlike traditional PHAs, MTW agencies are not held accountable through regulatory oversight but instead self-report their effectiveness to HUD. This structure is believed to promote program outcomes and long-term planning. The future of the MTW demonstration program is uncertain, with proposals to either expand it into a permanent program or phase it out in favor of targeted demonstrations for more meaningful evaluations. Critics call for its replacement with programs that allow for better policy changes informed by evaluations. The future of the MTW demonstration program is uncertain, with proposals to either expand it into a permanent program or phase it out in favor of targeted demonstrations for more meaningful evaluations. Policymakers are debating whether the MTW program should be a testing ground for new ideas or if it should become the future of assisted housing. The program aims to design and test approaches for providing housing assistance that reduce costs, promote work and self-sufficiency, and increase family choice. The Secretary of HUD evaluates participating agencies to identify replicable program models. The MTW demonstration program has limitations in effectively testing various approaches for housing assistance. Suggestions have been made to change MTW to better serve research-oriented purposes through targeted, temporary demonstrations. HUD has proposed expanding the program to 60 agencies for systematic evaluation, focusing on high-performing agencies and specific policies for study. HUD has emphasized selecting high-performing agencies for rigorous evaluation of policies implemented by MTW agencies. The MTW program was created as a compromise between transforming rental assistance programs into a block grant program and retaining existing programs. Calls to expand and make MTW a permanent program have increased due to its desirability among PHAs. Calls to expand and make MTW a permanent program have been increasing. The Moving to Work Charter Program Act aims to expand the program to 250 PHAs and make it permanent. There have been proposals to block grant and deregulate federal housing assistance for all PHAs, similar to MTW. Concerns have been raised about potential funding reductions and loss of tenant protections with a block grant model. HUD has concerns about the capacity of some agencies entering the MTW program, preferring high performers with proven ability to meet reporting requirements. They recommend selecting PHAs based on evaluation capacity, innovation, and local support. It is uncertain if the current MTW program or a fully deregulated block grant program would be suitable for small PHAs. Policymakers could choose to maintain the program as is, with existing agreements in place until 2018. The existing MTW agencies have agreements through 2018, with the possibility for extensions at HUD's discretion. Congress may add small numbers of additional agencies. HUD has addressed concerns by increasing reporting requirements and standardizing agreements. Participating PHAs will continue to experiment with new policies that may influence assisted housing programs. Both HUD and policymakers are considering incorporating reforms from MTW agencies. Obama Administration and Members of Congress have proposed changes to rental assistance programs based on MTW policies. Some proposed changes to rental assistance programs include biennial inspections, changes to income calculation rules, rent policy adjustments, expanded authority for PHAs, and blending of operating and capital funding. There is bipartisan support for some reforms, but controversial policies remain, such as altering assistance amounts and imposing conditions like time limits and work requirements. Tenant advocates and researchers have concerns about the impact of these policies on tenant outcomes.
